description: This course is an introduction to programming and gives a good base for further studies within computational science, but it's also suited for those who just wish to understand what programming is. The course doesn't presuppose any knowledge of programming. It'll be given a beginners introduction to Python and how to develop algorithms, including the use of lists, files, and communication with the user. Particular emphasis is placed on object-oriented programming.

This course introduces fundamental concepts of calculus, including limits, derivatives, and integrals. Students will learn various techniques for solving mathematical problems involving functions and their rates of change. Applications of calculus in physics, engineering, and economics will be explored.

This course provides an introduction to the principles of quantum mechanics. Topics covered include wave-particle duality, Schr√∂dinger's equation, operators, and the mathematical formalism of quantum mechanics. Applications of quantum mechanics in atomic and molecular systems will be discussed.

This course covers the fundamental data structures and algorithms used in computer science. Topics include arrays, linked lists, stacks, queues, trees, graphs, sorting algorithms, and searching algorithms. Students will analyze the efficiency and performance of different data structures and algorithms.

This course introduces the principles of microeconomics, which focus on individual economic agents such as consumers, firms, and markets. Topics include supply and demand, market equilibrium, consumer behavior, production and costs, and market structures. The course also explores the role of government in the economy.

This course introduces students to experimental methods used in psychological research. Topics include research design, data collection techniques, statistical analysis, and ethical considerations. Students will conduct experiments and analyze data to gain practical experience in psychological research.

This course explores the behavior of materials under different loading conditions. Topics covered include stress, strain, elasticity, plasticity, and fracture mechanics. Students will learn to analyze and design structural components using the principles of mechanics of materials.

This course provides an overview of the history of art from ancient civilizations to the present day. Students will study various art movements, styles, and artists, analyzing the cultural, social, and historical contexts in which artworks were created. The course includes visits to museums and galleries.

This course introduces students to the basic principles and concepts of law. Topics covered include legal systems, sources of law, legal reasoning, and the role of law in society. Students will develop critical thinking and legal analysis skills through case studies and discussions.

This course covers the fundamentals of digital electronics and logic design. Students will learn about logic gates, Boolean algebra, combinational and sequential circuits, and memory devices. Practical applications of digital electronics in computer systems and other electronic devices will be explored.

This course provides an overview of marketing principles and strategies. Topics include market research, consumer behavior, product development, pricing, promotion, and distribution. Students will develop marketing plans and analyze case studies to understand the challenges and opportunities in marketing management.

This course introduces the principles of classical mechanics, which describe the motion of macroscopic objects. Topics covered include Newton's laws of motion, energy, momentum, rotational motion, and gravitation. Students will learn to apply these principles to analyze and solve mechanical problems.

This course provides a comprehensive introduction to the fundamental principles of chemistry. Topics covered include atomic structure, chemical bonding, stoichiometry, gas laws, solutions, acids and bases, and chemical reactions. Laboratory experiments will reinforce theoretical concepts.

This course focuses on the study of macroeconomic principles and policies. Topics covered include national income determination, economic growth, unemployment, inflation, monetary policy, fiscal policy, and international trade. Students will analyze real-world economic scenarios and their impact on macroeconomic variables.

This course introduces the principles and techniques of database systems. Topics covered include relational database design, SQL querying, normalization, transaction management, and database security. Students will gain hands-on experience by designing and implementing database systems.

This course provides an overview of world history from ancient civilizations to the present day. Students will study major historical events, cultural developments, and the interactions between different societies. The course aims to develop a global perspective and an understanding of historical processes.

This course explores the theories and practices of international relations. Topics covered include state sovereignty, power, diplomacy, globalization, international organizations, and conflict resolution. Students will analyze contemporary issues in international relations and evaluate different perspectives.

This course introduces the principles of thermodynamics, which study the behavior of energy and heat transfer in systems. Topics covered include the laws of thermodynamics, properties of pure substances, work and heat interactions, and thermodynamic cycles. Applications in engineering and environmental sciences will be discussed.

This course provides an introduction to the field of psychology. Topics covered include the history of psychology, biological bases of behavior, perception, learning, memory, motivation, and social behavior. Students will gain a foundational understanding of psychological theories and research methods.

This course examines ethical issues and dilemmas in the business environment. Topics include ethical decision-making, corporate social responsibility, stakeholder theory, whistle-blowing, and sustainability. Students will analyze case studies and develop ethical frameworks for business practices.

This course introduces the principles and techniques of artificial intelligence. Topics covered include problem-solving, knowledge representation, search algorithms, machine learning, natural language processing, and intelligent agents. Students will develop AI applications and explore the ethical implications of AI technology.

This course focuses on graphical communication in engineering. Students will learn to create technical drawings and models using computer-aided design (CAD) software. Topics covered include orthographic projections, dimensioning, sectioning, and assembly drawings.

This course explores major works of English literature from different periods and genres. Students will analyze literary techniques, themes, and historical contexts in selected texts. The course aims to develop critical reading and interpretation skills.

This course focuses on the study of organic compounds and their reactions. Topics covered include nomenclature, structure, bonding, stereochemistry, functional groups, and reaction mechanisms. Laboratory experiments will reinforce theoretical concepts.

This course introduces statistical methods used in economic analysis. Topics covered include regression analysis, hypothesis testing, time series analysis, and panel data models. Students will learn to apply econometric techniques to real-world economic data.

This course covers the principles and protocols of computer networks. Topics include network architectures, network layers, routing algorithms, congestion control, and network security. Students will gain practical experience in configuring and managing network systems.

This course focuses on the study of vector spaces, linear transformations, and matrices. Topics covered include systems of linear equations, eigenvalues and eigenvectors, determinants, and orthogonality. Applications of linear algebra in various fields will be explored.

This course explores the cognitive processes underlying perception, attention, memory, language, problem-solving, and decision-making. Students will learn about cognitive psychology theories and research methods through experimental studies and cognitive modeling.

This course focuses on the theory and techniques of computer vision, which enable computers to understand and interpret visual data. Topics covered include image processing, feature extraction, object recognition, and image-based modeling. Applications of computer vision in robotics, augmented reality, and autonomous vehicles will be discussed.

This course introduces the principles and practices of financial accounting. Topics covered include the accounting cycle, financial statements, revenue recognition, asset valuation, and financial analysis. Students will learn to prepare and interpret financial statements for decision-making.

This course focuses on the behavior of fluids at rest and in motion. Topics covered include fluid properties, fluid statics, fluid dynamics, flow measurement, and boundary layer theory. Applications in engineering, such as flow in pipes and around objects, will be discussed.

This course provides an introduction to statistical methods and data analysis. Topics covered include descriptive statistics, probability, hypothesis testing, confidence intervals, regression analysis, and analysis of variance. Students will use statistical software to analyze real-world datasets.

This course explores the principles of electromagnetism, which describe the behavior of electric and magnetic fields. Topics covered include electrostatics, magnetostatics, electromagnetic induction, Maxwell's equations, and electromagnetic waves. Applications in electrical circuits and devices will be discussed.

This course examines social behavior, institutions, and structures from a sociological perspective. Topics covered include socialization, culture, social inequality, social change, and sociological theories. Students will analyze social phenomena and apply sociological concepts to real-world issues.

This course focuses on the study of materials and their properties. Topics covered include atomic structure, crystallography, mechanical properties, phase diagrams, and materials processing. Students will learn about different types of materials, such as metals, ceramics, polymers, and composites.

This course examines major art movements and trends in modern and contemporary art. Students will study the works of influential artists and analyze the cultural, social, and political contexts in which they were created. The course includes visits to galleries and exhibitions.

This course explores the principles and concepts of constitutional law. Topics covered include the structure of government, individual rights and freedoms, judicial review, and constitutional interpretation. Students will analyze landmark constitutional cases and discuss contemporary issues in constitutional law.

This course focuses on the principles and practices of software engineering. Topics covered include software development life cycle, requirements engineering, software design, testing, and project management. Students will work on a software project to apply the concepts and techniques learned.

This course explores psychological disorders and their causes, symptoms, and treatments. Topics covered include anxiety disorders, mood disorders, personality disorders, schizophrenia, and substance abuse. Students will examine case studies and current research in abnormal psychology.

This course focuses on the principles of control systems and their applications in engineering. Topics covered include modeling and analysis of dynamic systems, feedback control, stability, and system response. Students will design and analyze control systems in various engineering domains.

This course examines the art and architecture of the Renaissance period. Students will study the works of prominent artists, such as Leonardo da Vinci, Michelangelo, and Raphael, and analyze the cultural, social, and intellectual transformations of the Renaissance era.

This course focuses on the principles and techniques of operations management in organizations. Topics covered include process design, capacity planning, inventory management, supply chain management, quality control, and project management. Students will analyze case studies and apply operations management concepts to real-world scenarios.

This course provides an introduction to the fundamental principles of physics. Topics covered include mechanics, thermodynamics, waves, optics, and electricity. Students will learn to apply physical laws and concepts to solve problems and understand natural phenomena.

This course focuses on the study of chemical systems using principles of physics. Topics covered include thermodynamics, quantum mechanics, spectroscopy, and kinetics. Students will learn to apply physical chemistry principles to understand chemical phenomena and reactions.

This course introduces the principles and algorithms of machine learning. Topics covered include supervised learning, unsupervised learning, reinforcement learning, and deep learning. Students will develop machine learning models and apply them to real-world datasets.

This course introduces the principles of engineering mechanics, which study the behavior of objects under the action of forces. Topics covered include statics, dynamics, kinematics, and Newton's laws of motion. Students will apply these principles to analyze and solve engineering problems.

This course focuses on the development of creative writing skills in various genres, such as fiction, poetry, and drama. Students will explore different writing techniques and styles, participate in workshops, and receive feedback on their own creative writing projects.

This course focuses on the theory and techniques of image processing, which enable the manipulation and analysis of digital images. Topics covered include image enhancement, restoration, segmentation, and feature extraction. Applications in computer vision, medical imaging, and multimedia will be discussed.

This course examines the principles and practices of strategic management in organizations. Topics covered include strategic analysis, formulation of business strategies, implementation of strategies, and evaluation of strategic performance. Students will analyze case studies and develop strategic plans.

This course explores the major theories and ideologies of politics. Topics covered include liberalism, conservatism, socialism, feminism, and postcolonialism. Students will analyze political texts, engage in debates, and critically evaluate different political perspectives.
